subject: update rpmlint-1.5 version
commitMessage:
update rpmlint-1.5 version

This patch updates rpmlint-1.5 version from openSUSE contributions.
This updates will be required since we upgrade the python 2.7.8 version.

Change-Id: I2f42be85e17856156dbcc90bdbe8ea3ae08fcc83
Signed-off-by: Chanho Park <chanho61.park@samsung.com>

subject: Enable Aarch64
commitMessage:
Enable Aarch64

Created symlink /opt/testing/lib -> /opt/testing/lib64

This is done in case when macro %{_lib} is not equal "lib"
(it's the case during the aarch64 build).

Without this patch all builds for architecture aarch64 will fail
because rpmlint will not be able to start because of the following
error:

[  199s] RPMLINT report:
[  199s] ===============
[  199s] qemu: Unsupported syscall: 219
[  199s] Could not find platform independent libraries <prefix>
[  199s] Could not find platform dependent libraries <exec_prefix>
[  199s] Consider setting $PYTHONHOME to <prefix>[:<exec_prefix>]
[  199s] ImportError: No module named site

Change-Id: I746bbc149c1f4446442035ea7b26d80cc56189a8
Signed-off-by: Ilya Palachev <i.palachev@samsung.com>

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.
Uploaded patch set 2.
Patch Set 2: Verified+1 Code-Review+1

Patch Set 2: Verified+1

The build was verfied in the following project:

https://build.tizen.org/project/show?project=devel%3Aarm_toolchain%3AMobile%3ABase
Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 2:

Wouldn't it be better to make whatever tries to access /opt/testing/lib (python?) also look for /opt/testing/lib64?

Patch Set 2:

The way that you suggest requires changes in python package, because it tries to find its modules in exact directory (that is hardcoded during python's build).

Such errors (when the package is installed to one directory, and somebody wants it to be located in another) were obtained by us in HUGE number of packages because of interesting (~random) behaviour of autotools installation process :)

That's why we decided to avoid this problem not by fixing tons (!) of build scripts written on m4, but by creating symlinks at the level of filesystem (see the chnage for package "filesystem"): /lib -> /usr/lib, /lib64 -> /usr/lib64, /usr/lib64 -> /usr/lib, /lib32 -> /usr/lib32.

That's why the same problem was fixed in this package by creating a symlink.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Thank you.
Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.

- Commit: 1be8d9a8d0522d67bad78572c6f218d4f5ac9f82 Enable Aarch64
